title: Charles Pratt, 1st Earl Camden
text:
Charles Pratt, 1st Earl Camden, <a href="Her%20Majesty%27s%20Most%20Honourable%20Privy%20Council">PC</a> (<a href="baptism">baptised</a> 21 March 1714 – 18 April 1794) was an <a href="England">English</a> <a href="lawyer">lawyer</a>, <a href="judge">judge</a> and <a href="Whig%20%28British%20political%20faction%29">Whig</a> <a href="politician">politician</a> who was first to hold the title of <a href="Marquess%20Camden">Earl Camden</a>. As a lawyer and judge he was a leading proponent of <a href="civil%20liberties">civil liberties</a>, championing the rights of the <a href="jury%20%28England%20and%20Wales%29">jury</a>, and limiting the powers of the <a href="Sovereign%20state">State</a> in leading cases such as "<a href="Entick%20v%20Carrington">Entick v Carrington</a>".
He held the offices of <a href="Chief%20Justice%20of%20the%20Common%20Pleas">Chief Justice of the Common Pleas</a>, <a href="Attorney%20General%20for%20England%20and%20Wales">Attorney-General</a> and <a href="Lord%20Chancellor">Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain</a>, and was a confidant of <a href="William%20Pitt%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Chatham">Pitt the Elder</a>, supporting Pitt in the controversies over <a href="John%20Wilkes">John Wilkes</a> and <a href="American%20independence">American independence</a>. However, he clung to office himself, even when Pitt was out of power, serving in the cabinet for fifteen years and under five different prime ministers.
During his life, Pratt played a leading role in opposing <a href="perpetual%20copyright">perpetual copyright</a>, resolving the <a href="Regency%20Bill">regency crisis of 1788</a> and in championing <a href="Libel%20Act%201792">Fox's Libel Bill</a>. He started the development of the settlement that was later to become <a href="Camden%20Town">Camden Town</a> in <a href="London">London</a>.
Early life.
Born in <a href="Kensington">Kensington</a> in 1714, he was a descendant of an old <a href="Devon">Devon</a> family of high standing, the third son of Sir <a href="John%20Pratt%20%28judge%29">John Pratt</a>, <a href="Chief%20Justice%20of%20the%20King%27s%20Bench">Chief Justice of the King's Bench</a> in the reign of <a href="George%20I%20of%20Great%20Britain">George I</a>. Charles's mother, Elizabeth, was the daughter of Rev. Hugh Wilson of Trefeglwys, and the aunt of landscape painter <a href="Richard%20Wilson%20%28painter%29">Richard Wilson</a>. He received his early education at <a href="Eton%20College">Eton</a>, where he became acquainted with <a href="William%20Pitt%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Chatham">William Pitt</a>, and <a href="King%27s%20College%2C%20Cambridge">King's College, Cambridge</a>. He had already developed an interest in <a href="constitutional%20law">constitutional law</a> and <a href="civil%20liberties">civil liberties</a>. In 1734 he became a <a href="Oxbridge%20Fellow">fellow</a> of his college, and in the following year obtained his degree of <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">BA</a>. Having adopted his father's profession, he had entered the <a href="Middle%20Temple">Middle Temple</a> in 1728, and ten years later he was <a href="called%20to%20the%20Bar">called to the Bar</a>.
Early years at the Bar.
He practised at first in the courts of <a href="common%20law">common law</a>, travelling also the western circuit. For some years his practice was so limited, and he became so much discouraged that he seriously thought of turning his back on the law and entering the church. He listened, however, to the advice of his friend Sir <a href="Robert%20Henley%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Northington">Robert Henley</a>, a brother barrister, and persevered, working on and waiting for success. Reputedly, once instructed as Henley's junior, Henley feigned illness so that Pratt could lead and earn the credit.
He was further aided by an advantageous marriage on 5 October 1749 to Elizabeth, daughter of Nicholas Jeffreys of the Priory, Brecknock, by whom he had a son <a href="John%20Pratt%2C%201st%20Marquess%20Camden">John Jeffreys</a>, his successor in title and estates, and four daughters, of whom the eldest, Frances, married <a href="Robert%20Stewart%2C%201st%20Marquess%20of%20Londonderry">Robert Stewart, 1st Marquess of Londonderry</a> on 7 June 1775.
The first case which brought him prominently into notice and gave him assurance of ultimate success was the government prosecution, in 1752, of a bookseller, William Owen. Owen had published a book "The Case of Alexander Murray, Esq; in an Appeal to the people of Great Britain" which the <a href="British%20House%20of%20Commons">House of Commons</a> had, by resolution of the House, condemned as "an impudent, malicious, scandalous and <a href="seditious%20libel">seditious libel</a>". The author had left the country so the weight of the government's censure fell on Owen. Pratt appeared in Owen's defence and his novel argument was that it was not the sole role of the <a href="jury%20%28England%20and%20Wales%29">jury</a> to determine the fact of publication but that it was further their right to assess the intent of a <a href="libel">libel</a>. In his summing up, the <a href="judge">judge</a>, <a href="Lord%20Chief%20Justice%20of%20England%20and%20Wales">Lord Chief Justice</a> Sir <a href="William%20Lee%20%28English%20judge%29">William Lee</a> directed the jury to find Owen <a href="guilt%20%28law%29">guilt</a>y as publication was proved and the intent of the contents was a <a href="question%20of%20law">question of law</a> for the judge, not a <a href="question%20of%20fact">question of fact</a> for the jury. The jury disagreed and <a href="acquittal">acquitted</a> Owen. Pratt was appointed <a href="King%27s%20Counsel">King's Counsel</a> in 1755, and knighted in December 1761.
Political career.
Since their youthful meeting at Eton, Pitt had continued to consult Pratt on legal and constitutional matters and Pratt became involved in the group that met at the <a href="Leicester%20Square">Leicester House</a> home of <a href="George%20III%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">George</a> <a href="Prince%20of%20Wales">Prince of Wales</a> and who were opposed to the government of <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Great%20Britain">Prime Minister</a> the <a href="Thomas%20Pelham-Holles%2C%201st%20Duke%20of%20Newcastle">Duke of Newcastle</a>. In 1756, Newcastle offered Pratt a <a href="judge">judge</a>ship but Pratt preferred to take the role of <a href="Attorney%20General%20to%20the%20Prince%20of%20Wales">Attorney General to the Prince of Wales</a>.
In July 1757, Pitt formed a <a href="coalition">coalition</a> government with Newcastle and insisted on Pratt's appointment as <a href="Attorney%20General%20for%20England%20and%20Wales">Attorney-General</a>. Pratt was preferred over <a href="Solicitor%20General%20for%20England%20and%20Wales">Solicitor General</a> <a href="Charles%20Yorke">Charles Yorke</a>. Yorke was the son of <a href="Philip%20Yorke%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Hardwicke">Lord Hardwicke</a>, a political ally of Newcastle who, as <a href="Lord%20Chancellor">Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain</a> had obstructed Pratt's career in favour of his own son. Though this led to an uncomfortable relationship between the two law officers of the Crown, it led to the landmark <a href="Pratt-Yorke%20opinion">Pratt-Yorke opinion</a> of 24 December 1757 whereby the pair distinguished overseas territories acquired by <a href="conquest%20%28military%29">conquest</a> from those acquired by private <a href="treaty">treaty</a>. They asserted that, while <a href="the%20Crown">the Crown</a> of <a href="Great%20Britain">Great Britain</a> enjoyed <a href="sovereignty">sovereignty</a> over both, only the property of the former was vested in the Crown. Though the original opinion related to the <a href="British%20East%20India%20Company">British East India Company</a>, it came to be applied elsewhere in the developing <a href="British%20Empire">British Empire</a>.
The same year he entered the <a href="British%20House%20of%20Commons">House of Commons</a> as <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament">Member of Parliament</a> (MP) for the borough of <a href="Downton%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Downton</a> in <a href="Wiltshire">Wiltshire</a>. He sat in <a href="Parliament%20of%20Great%20Britain">Parliament</a> for four years, but did not distinguish himself as a debater. He introduced the <a href="Habeas%20Corpus%20Bill%20of%201758">Habeas corpus Amendment Bill of 1758</a>, which was intended to extend the <a href="writ">writ</a> of "<a href="Habeas%20corpus">Habeas corpus</a>" from <a href="criminal%20law">criminal law</a> to <a href="civil%20law%20%28common%20law%29">civil</a> and political cases. Despite Pitt's support, the Bill fell in the <a href="House%20of%20Lords">House of Lords</a>. At the same time, his professional practice increased, particularly his <a href="Court%20of%20Chancery">Chancery</a> practice which made him financially secure and enabled him to purchase the Camden Place estate in <a href="Kent">Kent</a>.
As Attorney-General, Pratt prosecuted <a href="Florence%20Hensey">Florence Hensey</a>, an <a href="Ireland">Irishman</a> who had <a href="spying">spied</a> for <a href="France">France</a>, and <a href="John%20Shebbeare">John Shebbeare</a>, a violent party writer of the day. Shebbeare had published a libel against the government contained in his "Letters to the People of England", which were published in 1756–58. As evidence of Pratt's moderation in a period of passionate party warfare and frequent state trials, it is notable that this was the only official prosecution for libel that he started and that he maintained his earlier insistence that the decision lay with the jury. He led for the Crown in the prosecution of <a href="Laurence%20Shirley%2C%204th%20Earl%20Ferrers">Laurence Shirley, 4th Earl Ferrers</a> for the <a href="murder">murder</a> of a servant, a case that shocked <a href="Europe">Europe</a>an <a href="society">society</a>.
Wilkes and Entick.
Pratt lost his patron when Pitt left office in October 1761 but in January 1762, he resigned from the Commons, was raised to the bench as <a href="Chief%20Justice%20of%20the%20Common%20Pleas">Chief Justice of the Common Pleas</a>, received the customary <a href="knighthood">knighthood</a> and was sworn into the <a href="Her%20Majesty%27s%20Most%20Honourable%20Privy%20Council">Privy Council</a>.
The Common Pleas was not an obvious forum for a jurist with constitutional interest, dealing as it did principally with disputes between private parties. However, on 30 April 1763, <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament">Member of Parliament</a> <a href="John%20Wilkes">John Wilkes</a> was <a href="arrest">arrest</a>ed under a <a href="general%20warrant">general warrant</a> for alleged seditious libel in issue No.45 of "<a href="The%20North%20Briton">The North Briton</a>". Pratt freed Wilkes holding that <a href="parliamentary%20privilege">parliamentary privilege</a> gave him immunity from arrest on such a charge. The decision earned Pratt some favour with the radical faction in London and seems to have spurred him, over the summer of that year to encourage <a href="jury%20%28England%20and%20Wales%29">juries</a> to award disproportionate and excessive <a href="damages">damages</a> to <a href="Printer%20%28publisher%29">printers</a> unlawfully arrested over the same matter. Wilkes was awarded £1,000 (£127,000 at 2003 prices) and Pratt condemned the use of general warrants for entry and search. Pratt pronounced with decisive and almost passionate energy against their legality, thus giving voice to the strong feeling of the nation and winning for himself an extraordinary degree of popularity as one of the maintainers of English civil liberties. Honours fell thick upon him in the form of addresses from the <a href="City%20of%20London">City of London</a> and many large towns, and of presentations of freedom from various corporate bodies.
In 1762, the home of <a href="John%20Entick">John Entick</a> had been raided by officers of the Crown, searching for evidence of <a href="sedition">sedition</a>. In the case of "<a href="Entick%20v%20Carrington">Entick v Carrington</a>" (1765), Pratt held that the raids were unlawful as they were without authority in <a href="statute">statute</a> or in common law.
The American Stamp Act crisis.
On 17 July 1765 Pratt was created Baron Camden, of Camden Place, in Chislehurst, Kent, becoming a member of the <a href="House%20of%20Lords">House of Lords</a>. Prime Minister <a href="Charles%20Watson-Wentworth%2C%202nd%20Marquess%20of%20Rockingham">Lord Rockingham</a> had unsuccessfully made this, and other appointments, to curry favour with Pitt but Camden was not over-eager to get involved in the crisis surrounding the <a href="Stamp%20Act%201765">Stamp Act 1765</a>. Camden did attend the Commons on 14 January 1766 and his subsequent speeches on the matter in the Lords are so similar to Pitt's that he had clearly adopted the party line. He was one of only five Lords who voted against the <a href="Declaratory%20Act">Declaratory Act</a>, a resolution of the House insisting on parliament's right to <a href="tax">tax</a> colonies overseas. Camden insisted that taxation was predicated on consent and that consent needed representation. However, when he came to support the government over the Act's <a href="repeal">repeal</a>, he rather unconvincingly purported to base his opinion on the actual hardship caused by the Act rather than its constitutional basis.
Lord Chancellor.
In May 1766, Pitt again became prime minister and advanced Camden from the court of common pleas to take his seat as <a href="Lord%20Chancellor">Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain</a> on 30 July. Camden managed to negotiate an additional allowance of £1500 and a position for his son John. Camden carried out the role in an efficient manner, without any great legal innovation. He presided over the <a href="Court%20of%20Chancery">Court of Chancery</a> from which only one of his decisions was overturned on appeal. He also presided over the <a href="judicial%20functions%20of%20the%20House%20of%20Lords">judicial functions of the House of Lords</a> where in 1767 he approved <a href="William%20Murray%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Mansfield">Lord Mansfield</a>'s ruling that the <a href="City%20of%20London">City of London</a> could not <a href="Fine%20%28penalty%29">fine</a> <a href="dissenter">dissenter</a>s who refused to serve the corporation. Dissenters were in any case prohibited from serving under the <a href="Corporation%20Act%201661">Corporation Act 1661</a>. In 1768 in the House of Lords he again sat in a case involving John Wilkes, this time rejecting his <a href="appeal">appeal</a> and finding that his consecutive, rather than concurrent <a href="sentence%20%28law%29">sentence</a>s were lawful. He gave a controversial judgment in the <a href="Douglas%20Cause">Douglas Peerage case</a>.
"A forty days tyranny".
However, Camden the politician was less of a champion of civil rights than Pratt the judge. The poor <a href="harvest">harvest</a> of 1766 led to fears of high grain prices and <a href="starvation">starvation</a> but parliament was <a href="legislative%20session%23Procedure%20in%20Commonwealth%20realms">prorogued</a> and could not renew the <a href="export">export</a> ban that expired on 26 August. Pitt, with Camden's support, called the Privy Council to issue a <a href="royal%20proclamation">royal proclamation</a> on 26 September to prohibit grain exports until parliament met. However, despite Camden's record on civil liberties, this proclamation was unlawful, contrary to art.2 of the <a href="Bill%20of%20Rights%201689">Bill of Rights 1689</a> and both houses of parliament ultimately accused Pitt and Camden of <a href="tyranny">tyranny</a>. Camden pleaded necessity, a justification he had rejected in the Wilkes and Carrington <a href="trial%20%28law%29">trial</a>s, and styled it "a forty days tyranny". Ultimately the government was forced to suppress the parliamentary attacks by an <a href="Act%20of%20Parliament">act</a> indemnifying those involved from legal action.
America.
In 1767, the <a href="Cabinet%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">cabinet</a>, of which Camden was a member, approved <a href="Charles%20Townshend">Charles Townshend</a>'s attempt to settle the American protest and revolt over taxation. <a href="Benjamin%20Franklin">Benjamin Franklin</a> reportedly observed that it was "internal" taxes that the colonists objected to and Townshend took this to suggest that there would be little opposition to <a href="import%20duty">import duties</a> imposed at the <a href="port">port</a>s. Camden's support for the tax proposals would return to embarrass him.
Pitt and his followers had, after their initial opposition, come to support the <a href="Declaratory%20Act">Declaratory Act</a> of 1766 which asserted Great Britain's sovereignty over the American colonies. Further, continued unrest in America, stemming from Townshend's 1767 taxation scheme, brought a robust response from Pitt and Camden was his spokesman in the Lords. However, towards the end of 1767, Pitt, now raised to the Lords as Earl Chatham, fell ill and the <a href="Augustus%20FitzRoy%2C%203rd%20Duke%20of%20Grafton">Duke of Grafton</a> stepped in as caretaker. Camden became indecisive in his own political role, writing to Grafton on 4 October 1768: 
Pitt resigned on 14 October and Camden, who continued to sit in the cabinet as Lord Chancellor, now took up a position of uncompromising hostility to the governments of Grafton and <a href="Frederick%20North%2C%20Lord%20North">Lord North</a> on America and on Wilkes. Camden opposed <a href="Wills%20Hill%2C%201st%20Marquess%20of%20Downshire">Lord Hillsborough</a>'s confrontational approach to the Americas, favouring conciliation and working on the development of reformed tax proposals. Camden personally promised the colonies that no further taxes would be levied, and voted in the cabinet minority who sought to repeal the tea duty.
John Wilkes MP.
On 28 March 1768, Wilkes was surprisingly elected as member for <a href="Middlesex%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Middlesex</a>, much to Grafton's distaste. Grafton canvassed Camden on whether Wilkes could be removed from parliament and Camden responded that, under the <a href="parliamentary%20privilege">parliamentary privilege</a> of the House to regulate its own membership, Wilkes could, though lawfully elected, be lawfully expelled. However, Camden saw that this was only likely to lead to Wilkes's re-election and an escalating crisis. The cabinet decided to seek Wilkes's expulsion but Camden was not content with the policy. By the end of 1769 he was in open opposition to the government and was making little contribution to discussions in cabinet. Only Royal pressure kept him in post. However, by the beginning of 1770, Chatham had returned to the fray, opposing government policies on Wilkes and America. On 9 January 1770, Chatham moved a motion opposing the government's policies and Camden stepped down from the <a href="woolsack">woolsack</a> to give a speech in support of the motion. However, he did not resign as Lord Chancellor until <a href="George%20III%20of%20Great%20Britain">King George III</a>, outraged by his conduct, demanded his dismissal on 17 January. He seems also to have resigned as a Chancery judge in late 1769.
Working Lord.
Into opposition.
Chatham, Rockingham and Grenville were expected to combine to bring down Grafton, when it was expected that Lord Camden would return to the woolsack. However, though Grafton resigned, <a href="Frederick%20North%2C%20Lord%20North">Lord North</a> managed to form a successor administration and Camden was left to opposition, continuing to sit in the Lords. From 1770 onwards, Chatham neglected parliamentary attendance and left leadership of the house to <a href="William%20Petty%2C%202nd%20Earl%20of%20Shelburne">Lord Shelburne</a> with whom Camden could manage only the coolest of relationships.
During 1770–71, Camden tussled with <a href="Earl%20of%20Mansfield%20and%20Mansfield">Lord Mansfield</a> over the law of <a href="libel">libel</a>, Camden maintaining that the <a href="jury%20%28England%20and%20Wales%29">jury</a> should not only decide whether the work in question was published but also whether the words themselves were <a href="defamation">defamatory</a> or innocent. He opposed the extension of the <a href="Royal%20Marriages%20Act%201772">Royal Marriages Act 1772</a> to all descendants of <a href="George%20II%20of%20Great%20Britain">King George II</a>, believing it to be impractical. In 1774, in the House of Lords <a href="appeal%20%28law%29">appeal</a> in the case of "<a href="Donaldson%20v%20Beckett">Donaldson v Beckett</a>", Camden spoke against the concept of <a href="perpetual%20copyright">perpetual copyright</a> for fear of inhibiting the advancement of learning. This was a key influence on the ultimate rejection of that year's <a href="Booksellers%27%20Bill">Booksellers' Bill</a>.
The American crisis of 1774.
The year 1774 brought a renewed crisis over America. The <a href="Boston%20Tea%20Party">Boston Tea Party</a> in 1773 led Lord North to seek a <a href="blockade">blockade</a> of the city through the <a href="Boston%20Port%20Bill">Boston Port Bill</a>. Camden roundly criticised the taxes that had led to the American protests, as he had opposed them in Cabinet from 1767 to 1769, but was reminded that he was Lord Chancellor when they were imposed. The Chathamite faction went on to support the Bill and further to support the <a href="Massachusetts%20Government%20Act">Massachusetts Government Act</a>, Camden's inherent <a href="patriotism">patriotism</a> bringing him into line. However, by May, fears that the Bill would focus and strengthen American resistance led Camden to oppose the measure.
On 16 February 1775, Camden made his major speech on the crisis, opposing public opinion and the <a href="New%20England%20Trade%20and%20Fishery%20Bill">New England Trade and Fishery Bill</a>, a speech often believed to have been drafted in collaboration with <a href="Benjamin%20Franklin">Benjamin Franklin</a> for an American audience. Camden invoked <a href="John%20Locke">John Locke</a>'s dictum that resistance to tyranny was justified and called the Bill:
<a href="Thomas%20Hutchinson%20%28governor%29">Thomas Hutchinson</a> observed:
How Camden voted on the <a href="Quebec%20Act">Quebec Act</a> is unknown but in May 1775, and in response to a <a href="petition">petition</a> from a small number of settlers, he unsuccessfully moved its <a href="repeal">repeal</a>. However, he seems to have been in the grip of a <a href="conspiracy%20theory">conspiracy theory</a> that the Act's ulterior objective was to create an army of militant <a href="Roman%20Catholics">Roman Catholics</a> in <a href="Canada">Canada</a> to suppress the <a href="Protestantism">Protestant</a> British colonists.
American War of Independence.
The <a href="American%20War%20of%20Independence">American War of Independence</a> broke out in 1775 and Chatham's faction were dismayed. Their official line was to advocate mediation, refusing to think of either American independence or continued English hegemony. Camden continued to speak on the dilemma in parliament. He continued steadfastly to oppose the taxation of the American colonists, and signed, in 1778, the protest of the <a href="House%20of%20Lords">Lords</a> in favour of an address to the King on the subject of the manifesto of the commissioners to America. In 1782 he was appointed <a href="Lord%20President%20of%20the%20Council">Lord President of the Council</a> under the Rockingham-Shelburne administration, supporting the government economic programme and anti-corruption drive, and championing repeal of the <a href="Declaratory%20Act%201720">Declaratory Act 1720</a> in <a href="Ireland">Ireland</a>. Once Rockingham died in July, the Chathamite residue could only lose the Commons vote over the <a href="American%20Revolutionary%20War%23Treaty%20of%20Paris">American peace terms</a> the following February. Camden resigned and persuaded Shelburne to do the same.
The Younger Pitt.
Camden was a leading opponent of the ensuing <a href="Fox-North%20Coalition">Fox-North Coalition</a>, denouncing it for <a href="patronage">patronage</a> and leading the opposition to <a href="Charles%20James%20Fox">Fox's</a> <a href="East%20India%20Bill">East India Bill</a> that brought down the administration on 9 December 1783. <a href="William%20Pitt%20the%20Younger">William Pitt the Younger</a>, the son of his former patron, came to power and within a few months Camden was reinstated as Lord President, holding the post until his death. He was created Earl Camden on 13 May 1786 and granted a further <a href="peerage">peerage</a> as Viscount Bayham to lend his son a <a href="courtesy%20title">courtesy title</a>.
Camden took an animated part in the debates on important public matters till within two years of his death, in particular supporting Pitt's 1785 Parliamentary Reform Bill and the <a href="Ireland">Irish</a> trade proposals that same year. Camden continued to attend cabinet meetings and, after he moved to Hill Street, <a href="Berkeley%20Square">Berkeley Square</a> on account of his ill health, cabinet meetings were sometimes held at his home.
Regency crisis of 1788.
In November 1788, <a href="George%20III%20of%20Great%20Britain">King George III</a> fell ill and <a href="insanity">insanity</a> was feared. Lord Chancellor <a href="Edward%20Thurlow%2C%201st%20Baron%20Thurlow">Thurlow</a> hesitated over what action to take, thereby precipitating the <a href="Regency%20Bill">regency crisis of 1788</a>. As Lord President, Camden led the <a href="Her%20Majesty%27s%20Most%20Honourable%20Privy%20Council">Privy Council</a> examination of the King's doctors' opinions. With Thurlow unwilling to lead the legislature, Camden grasped the challenge of inviting parliament to appoint a <a href="regent">regent</a>, in the face of the opposition's support for the automatic appointment of their ally the <a href="George%20IV%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Prince of Wales</a>. Camden's resolution that appointment rested with parliament was carried in the Lords by 99 votes to 66 on 23 December 1788. Moreover, on 22 January 1789, Camden's motion to appoint the Prince of Wales, but with restrictions in case of the King's recovery, was carried by 94 to 68 votes. The King recovered the following month before the Regency Bill contained force of law.
Fox's Libel Act.
To the last, Camden zealously defended his early views on the functions of juries, especially of their right to decide on all questions of libel. In the Lords debate on the <a href="second%20reading">second reading</a> of the <a href="Libel%20Act%201792">Libel Act 1792</a> on 16 May, Camden contended that <a href="intention%20%28criminal%20law%29">intention</a> was an essential element of libel and should be decided by the jury as in <a href="murder">murder</a> cases. Broadening the legal argument to the constitutional and political Camden charged <a href="press%20freedom">press freedom</a> to the hands of the jury as the representatives of the people. The judges he held were too prone to government pressure to guarantee essential freedoms. Despite the unanimous opposition of the <a href="Law%20Lords">Law Lords</a>, Camden's speech helped secure a majority of 57 to 32.
Reputation and legacy.
Camden was short in stature but of a fine physique. For recreation he enjoyed <a href="music">music</a>, <a href="theatre">theatre</a>, <a href="Romance%20novel">romantic fiction</a>, <a href="conversation">conversation</a> and <a href="food">food</a>. His vices were sloth and gluttony rather than womanising or <a href="gambling">gambling</a>. The Earl Camden died in <a href="London">London</a> on 18 April 1794. His remains were interred in Seal church in Kent. Camden died a wealthy man, much of his wealth deriving from his wife.
Both <a href="John%20Campbell%2C%201st%20Baron%20Campbell">Lord Campbell</a> and Sir <a href="William%20Searle%20Holdsworth">William Holdsworth</a> held Camden a great Lord Chancellor.
By the 20th century, Camden's legal opinions were seen as subservient to Chatham's politics and Camden certainly followed the party line on Wilkes and America. However, his party loyalty was tempered by a self-serving interest in power. He served under five prime ministers and on two occasions clung to office after Chatham had resigned.
In his last years he took a great interest in the career of <a href="Robert%20Stewart%2C%202nd%20Marquess%20of%20Londonderry">Robert Stewart, 2nd Marquess of Londonderry</a>, his daughter's stepson. Camden, whose own son was not to prove much of a statesman, recognised young Robert's potential and treated him very much as though he was his actual grandson.
In 1788 he obtained an <a href="Act%20of%20Parliament">Act of Parliament</a> granting permission to develop some fields he owned just to the north of London. In 1791 he laid out the land in plots and <a href="lease">lease</a>d them for the construction of 1,400 houses, the beginnings of <a href="Camden%20Town">Camden Town</a>.
The town of <a href="Camden%2C%20Maine">Camden</a>, <a href="Maine">Maine</a> in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, was named for him in 1791. This is one of several cities, towns, and counties bearing his name, including <a href="Camden%2C%20South%20Carolina">Camden</a>, <a href="South%20Carolina">South Carolina</a>, <a href="Camden%2C%20North%20Carolina">Camden</a>, <a href="North%20Carolina">North Carolina</a>, and <a href="Camden%2C%20New%20Jersey">Camden</a>, <a href="New%20Jersey">New Jersey</a>, as well as Camden Counties in <a href="Camden%20County%2C%20New%20Jersey">New Jersey</a> (of which the eponymous city is the seat and largest city), <a href="Camden%20County%2C%20Missouri">Missouri</a> and <a href="Camden%20County%2C%20Georgia">Georgia</a>. In turn, Camden, South Carolina gave its name both to the <a href="Battle%20of%20Camden">Battle of Camden</a> and <a href="Camden%2C%20Alabama">Camden</a>, Alabama. <a href="Camden%2C%20Tennessee">Camden</a>, <a href="Tennessee">Tennessee</a> was named for the battle, and <a href="Camden%2C%20Arkansas">Camden</a>, <a href="Arkansas">Arkansas</a> took its name from the town in Alabama. Furthermore, Pratt Street, a major thoroughfare in <a href="Baltimore">Baltimore</a>, is also named partially after him.
